name: SecureSocket
comment: A high-level class for communicating securely over a TCP socket, using TLS and SSL. The dart-io.SecureSocket exposes both a dart-async.Stream and an dart-io.IOSink interface, making it ideal for using together with other dart-async.Streams.

encoding.name: encoding
encoding.comment: The dart-convert.Encoding used when writing strings. Depending on the underlying consumer this property might be mutable.

peerCertificate.name: peerCertificate
peerCertificate.comment: Get the peer certificate for a connected SecureSocket. If this SecureSocket is the server end of a secure socket connection, dart-io.SecureSocket.peerCertificate will return the client certificate, or null, if no client certificate was received. If it is the client end, dart-io.SecureSocket.peerCertificate will return the server's certificate.

connect.name: connect
connect.comment:
Constructs a new secure client socket and connect it to the given dart-io.SecureSocket.connect.host on port dart-io.SecureSocket.connect.port. The returned Future will complete with a dart-io.SecureSocket that is connected and ready for subscription.

If dart-io.SecureSocket.connect.sendClientCertificate is set to true, the socket will send a client certificate if one is requested by the server.

If dart-io.SecureSocket.connect.certificateName is the nickname of a certificate in the certificate database, that certificate will be sent.

If dart-io.SecureSocket.connect.certificateName is null, which is the usual use case, an appropriate certificate will be searched for in the database and sent automatically, based on what the server says it will accept.

dart-io.SecureSocket.connect.onBadCertificate is an optional handler for unverifiable certificates. The handler receives the dart-io.X509Certificate, and can inspect it and decide (or let the user decide) whether to accept the connection or not. The handler should return true to continue the dart-io.SecureSocket connection.

secure.name: secure
secure.comment:
Takes an already connected dart-io.SecureSocket.secure.socket and starts client side TLS handshake to make the communication secure. When the returned future completes the dart-io.SecureSocket has completed the TLS handshake. Using this function requires that the other end of the connection is prepared for TLS handshake.

If the dart-io.SecureSocket.secure.socket already has a subscription, this subscription will no longer receive and events. In most cases calling pause on this subscription before starting TLS handshake is the right thing to do.

If the dart-io.SecureSocket.secure.host argument is passed it will be used as the host name for the TLS handshake. If dart-io.SecureSocket.secure.host is not passed the host name from the dart-io.SecureSocket.secure.socket will be used. The dart-io.SecureSocket.secure.host can be either a dart-core.String or an dart-io.InternetAddress.

Calling this function will not cause a DNS host lookup. If the dart-io.SecureSocket.secure.host passed is a dart-core.String the dart-io.InternetAddress for the resulting dart-io.SecureSocket will have the passed in dart-io.SecureSocket.secure.host as its host value and the internet address of the already connected socket as its address value.

See dart-io.SecureSocket.connect for more information on the arguments.

secureServer.name: secureServer
secureServer.comment:
Takes an already connected dart-io.SecureSocket.secureServer.socket and starts server side TLS handshake to make the communication secure. When the returned future completes the dart-io.SecureSocket has completed the TLS handshake. Using this function requires that the other end of the connection is going to start the TLS handshake.

If the dart-io.SecureSocket.secureServer.socket already has a subscription, this subscription will no longer receive and events. In most cases calling pause on this subscription before starting TLS handshake is the right thing to do.

If some of the data of the TLS handshake has already been read from the socket this data can be passed in the dart-io.SecureSocket.secureServer.bufferedData parameter. This data will be processed before any other data available on the socket.

See dart-io.SecureServerSocket.bind for more information on the arguments.

renegotiate.name: renegotiate
renegotiate.comment:
Renegotiate an existing secure connection, renewing the session keys and possibly changing the connection properties.

This repeats the SSL or TLS handshake, with options that allow clearing the session cache and requesting a client certificate.

initialize.name: initialize
initialize.comment:
Initializes the NSS library. If dart-io.SecureSocket.initialize is not called, the library is automatically initialized as if dart-io.SecureSocket.initialize were called with no arguments. If dart-io.SecureSocket.initialize is called more than once, or called after automatic initialization has happened (when a secure connection is made), then a TlsException is thrown.

The optional argument dart-io.SecureSocket.initialize.database is the path to a certificate database directory containing root certificates for verifying certificate paths on client connections, and server certificates to provide on server connections. The argument dart-io.SecureSocket.initialize.password should be used when creating secure server sockets, to allow the private key of the server certificate to be fetched. If dart-io.SecureSocket.initialize.useBuiltinRoots is true (the default), then a built-in set of root certificates for trusted certificate authorities is merged with the certificates in the database. The list of built-in root certificates, and documentation about this default database, is available at http://www.mozilla.org/projects/security/certs/included/ .

If the dart-io.SecureSocket.initialize.database argument is omitted, then only the builtin root certificates are used. If dart-io.SecureSocket.initialize.useBuiltinRoots is also false, then no certificates are available.

Examples: 1) Use only the builtin root certificates:

SecureSocket.initialize(); or

2) Use a specified database directory and the builtin roots:

SecureSocket.initialize(database: 'path/to/my/database',
                        password: 'my_password');

3) Use a specified database directory, without builtin roots:

SecureSocket.initialize(database: 'path/to/my/database',
                        password: 'my_password'.
                        useBuiltinRoots: false);

The database should be an NSS certificate database directory containing a cert9.db file, not a cert8.db file. This version of the database can be created using the NSS certutil tool with "sql:" in front of the absolute path of the database directory, or setting the environment variable [NSS_DEFAULT_DB_TYPE] to "sql".

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides dart-io.SecureSocket.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

done.name: done
done.comment: Get a future that will complete when the consumer closes, or when an error occurs. This future is identical to the future returned by dart-io.SecureSocket.close.

isBroadcast.name: isBroadcast
isBroadcast.comment: Reports whether this stream is a broadcast stream.

isEmpty.name: isEmpty
isEmpty.comment:
Reports whether this stream contains any elements.

Stops listening to the stream after the first element has been received.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after the first element. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this getter.

first.name: first
first.comment:
Returns the first element of the stream.

Stops listening to the stream after the first element has been received.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after the first element. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this getter.

If an error event occurs before the first data event, the resulting future is completed with that error.

If this stream is empty (a done event occurs before the first data event), the resulting future completes with a dart-core.StateError.

Except for the type of the error, this method is equivalent to this.elementAt(0).

last.name: last
last.comment:
Returns the last element of the stream.

If an error event occurs before the first data event, the resulting future is completed with that error.

If this stream is empty (a done event occurs before the first data event), the resulting future completes with a dart-core.StateError.

single.name: single
single.comment:
Returns the single element.

If an error event occurs before or after the first data event, the resulting future is completed with that error.

If this is empty or has more than one element throws a dart-core.StateError.

port.name: port
port.comment: Returns the port used by this socket.

remotePort.name: remotePort
remotePort.comment: Returns the remote port connected to by this socket.

address.name: address
address.comment: Returns the dart-io.InternetAddress used to connect this socket.

remoteAddress.name: remoteAddress
remoteAddress.comment: Returns the remote dart-io.InternetAddress connected to by this socket.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and dart-io.SecureSocket.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the dart-io.SecureSocket.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
dart-io.SecureSocket.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to dart-io.SecureSocket.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If dart-io.SecureSocket.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of dart-io.SecureSocket.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.

write.name: write
write.comment:
Converts dart-io.SecureSocket.write.obj to a String by invoking dart-io.SecureSocket.toString and dart-io.SecureSocket.adds the encoding of the result to the target consumer.

This operation is non-blocking. See dart-io.SecureSocket.flush or dart-io.SecureSocket.done for how to get any errors generated by this call.

writeAll.name: writeAll
writeAll.comment:
Iterates over the given dart-io.SecureSocket.writeAll.objects and dart-io.SecureSocket.writes them in sequence.

If dart-io.SecureSocket.writeAll.separator is provided, a write with the separator is performed between any two elements of objects.

This operation is non-blocking. See dart-io.SecureSocket.flush or dart-io.SecureSocket.done for how to get any errors generated by this call.

writeln.name: writeln
writeln.comment:
Converts dart-io.SecureSocket.writeln.obj to a String by invoking dart-io.SecureSocket.toString and writes the result to this, followed by a newline.

This operation is non-blocking. See dart-io.SecureSocket.flush or dart-io.SecureSocket.done for how to get any errors generated by this call.

writeCharCode.name: writeCharCode
writeCharCode.comment:
Writes the dart-io.SecureSocket.writeCharCode.charCode to this.

This method is equivalent to write(new String.fromCharCode(charCode)).

This operation is non-blocking. See dart-io.SecureSocket.flush or dart-io.SecureSocket.done for how to get any errors generated by this call.

add.name: add
add.comment:
Adds dart-io.SecureSocket.add.data to the target consumer, ignoring dart-io.IOSink.encoding.

The dart-io.IOSink.encoding does not apply to this method, and the data list is passed directly to the target consumer as a stream event.

This function must not be called when a stream is currently being added using dart-io.SecureSocket.addStream.

This operation is non-blocking. See dart-io.SecureSocket.flush or dart-io.SecureSocket.done for how to get any errors generated by this call.

The data list should not be modified after it has been passed to add.

addError.name: addError
addError.comment:
Passes the error to the target consumer as an error event.

This function must not be called when a stream is currently being added using dart-io.SecureSocket.addStream.

This operation is non-blocking. See dart-io.SecureSocket.flush or dart-io.SecureSocket.done for how to get any errors generated by this call.

addStream.name: addStream
addStream.comment: Adds all elements of the given dart-io.SecureSocket.addStream.stream to this.

flush.name: flush
flush.comment:
Returns a dart-async.Future that completes once all buffered data is accepted by the to underlying dart-async.StreamConsumer.

It's an error to call this method, while an dart-io.SecureSocket.addStream is incomplete.

NOTE: This is not necessarily the same as the data being flushed by the operating system.

asBroadcastStream.name: asBroadcastStream
asBroadcastStream.comment:
Returns a multi-subscription stream that produces the same events as this.

If this stream is already a broadcast stream, it is returned unmodified.

If this stream is single-subscription, return a new stream that allows multiple subscribers. It will subscribe to this stream when its first subscriber is added, and will stay subscribed until this stream ends, or a callback cancels the subscription.

If dart-io.SecureSocket.asBroadcastStream.onListen is provided, it is called with a subscription-like object that represents the underlying subscription to this stream. It is possible to pause, resume or cancel the subscription during the call to dart-io.SecureSocket.asBroadcastStream.onListen. It is not possible to change the event handlers, including using dart-async.StreamSubscription.asFuture.

If dart-io.SecureSocket.asBroadcastStream.onCancel is provided, it is called in a similar way to dart-io.SecureSocket.asBroadcastStream.onListen when the returned stream stops having listener. If it later gets a new listener, the dart-io.SecureSocket.asBroadcastStream.onListen function is called again.

Use the callbacks, for example, for pausing the underlying subscription while having no subscribers to prevent losing events, or canceling the subscription when there are no listeners.

listen.name: listen
listen.comment:
Adds a subscription to this stream.

On each data event from this stream, the subscriber's dart-io.SecureSocket.listen.onData handler is called. If dart-io.SecureSocket.listen.onData is null, nothing happens.

On errors from this stream, the dart-io.SecureSocket.listen.onError handler is given a object describing the error.

The dart-io.SecureSocket.listen.onError callback must be of type void onError(error) or void onError(error, StackTrace stackTrace). If dart-io.SecureSocket.listen.onError accepts two arguments it is called with the stack trace (which could be null if the stream itself received an error without stack trace). Otherwise it is called with just the error object.

If this stream closes, the dart-io.SecureSocket.listen.onDone handler is called.

If dart-io.SecureSocket.listen.cancelOnError is true, the subscription is ended when the first error is reported. The default is false.

where.name: where
where.comment:
Creates a new stream from this stream that discards some data events.

The new stream sends the same error and done events as this stream, but it only sends the data events that satisfy the dart-io.SecureSocket.where.test.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

map.name: map
map.comment:
Creates a new stream that converts each element of this stream to a new value using the dart-io.SecureSocket.map.convert function.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

asyncMap.name: asyncMap
asyncMap.comment:
Creates a new stream with each data event of this stream asynchronously mapped to a new event.

This acts like dart-io.SecureSocket.map, except that dart-io.SecureSocket.asyncMap.convert may return a dart-async.Future, and in that case, the stream waits for that future to complete before continuing with its result.

asyncExpand.name: asyncExpand
asyncExpand.comment:
Creates a new stream with the events of a stream per original event.

This acts like dart-io.SecureSocket.expand, except that dart-io.SecureSocket.asyncExpand.convert returns a dart-async.Stream instead of an dart-core.Iterable. The events of the returned stream becomes the events of the returned stream, in the order they are produced.

If dart-io.SecureSocket.asyncExpand.convert returns null, no value is put on the output stream, just as if it returned an empty stream.

handleError.name: handleError
handleError.comment:
Creates a wrapper Stream that intercepts some errors from this stream.

If this stream sends an error that matches dart-io.SecureSocket.handleError.test, then it is intercepted by the handle function.

The dart-io.SecureSocket.handleError.onError callback must be of type void onError(error) or void onError(error, StackTrace stackTrace). Depending on the function type the the stream either invokes dart-io.SecureSocket.handleError.onError with or without a stack trace. The stack trace argument might be null if the stream itself received an error without stack trace.

An asynchronous error e is matched by a test function if test(e) returns true. If dart-io.SecureSocket.handleError.test is omitted, every error is considered matching.

If the error is intercepted, the handle function can decide what to do with it. It can throw if it wants to raise a new (or the same) error, or simply return to make the stream forget the error.

If you need to transform an error into a data event, use the more generic dart-io.SecureSocket.transform to handle the event by writing a data event to the output sink

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

expand.name: expand
expand.comment:
Creates a new stream from this stream that converts each element into zero or more events.

Each incoming event is converted to an dart-core.Iterable of new events, and each of these new events are then sent by the returned stream in order.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

pipe.name: pipe
pipe.comment: Binds this stream as the input of the provided dart-async.StreamConsumer.

transform.name: transform
transform.comment:
Chains this stream as the input of the provided dart-async.StreamTransformer.

Returns the result of streamTransformer.bind itself.

reduce.name: reduce
reduce.comment: Reduces a sequence of values by repeatedly applying dart-io.SecureSocket.reduce.combine.

fold.name: fold
fold.comment: Reduces a sequence of values by repeatedly applying dart-io.SecureSocket.fold.combine.

join.name: join
join.comment:
Collects string of data events' string representations.

If dart-io.SecureSocket.join.separator is provided, it is inserted between any two elements.

Any error in the stream causes the future to complete with that error. Otherwise it completes with the collected string when the "done" event arrives.

contains.name: contains
contains.comment:
Checks whether dart-io.SecureSocket.contains.needle occurs in the elements provided by this stream.

Completes the dart-async.Future when the answer is known. If this stream reports an error, the dart-async.Future will report that error.

forEach.name: forEach
forEach.comment:
Executes dart-io.SecureSocket.forEach.action on each data event of the stream.

Completes the returned dart-async.Future when all events of the stream have been processed. Completes the future with an error if the stream has an error event, or if dart-io.SecureSocket.forEach.action throws.

every.name: every
every.comment:
Checks whether dart-io.SecureSocket.every.test accepts all elements provided by this stream.

Completes the dart-async.Future when the answer is known. If this stream reports an error, the dart-async.Future will report that error.

any.name: any
any.comment:
Checks whether dart-io.SecureSocket.any.test accepts any element provided by this stream.

Completes the dart-async.Future when the answer is known.

If this stream reports an error, the dart-async.Future reports that error.

Stops listening to the stream after the first matching element has been found.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after this element. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this method.

toList.name: toList
toList.comment: Collects the data of this stream in a dart-core.List.

toSet.name: toSet
toSet.comment: Collects the data of this stream in a dart-core.Set.

drain.name: drain
drain.comment:
Discards all data on the stream, but signals when it's done or an error occured.

When subscribing using dart-io.SecureSocket.drain, cancelOnError will be true. This means that the future will complete with the first error on the stream and then cancel the subscription.

In case of a done event the future completes with the given dart-io.SecureSocket.drain.futureValue.

take.name: take
take.comment:
Provides at most the first n values of this stream.

Forwards the first n data events of this stream, and all error events, to the returned stream, and ends with a done event.

If this stream produces fewer than dart-io.SecureSocket.take.count values before it's done, so will the returned stream.

Stops listening to the stream after the first n elements have been received.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after these elements. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this method.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

takeWhile.name: takeWhile
takeWhile.comment:
Forwards data events while dart-io.SecureSocket.takeWhile.test is successful.

The returned stream provides the same events as this stream as long as dart-io.SecureSocket.takeWhile.test returns true for the event data. The stream is done when either this stream is done, or when this stream first provides a value that dart-io.SecureSocket.takeWhile.test doesn't accept.

Stops listening to the stream after the accepted elements.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after these elements. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this method.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

skip.name: skip
skip.comment:
Skips the first dart-io.SecureSocket.skip.count data events from this stream.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

skipWhile.name: skipWhile
skipWhile.comment:
Skip data events from this stream while they are matched by dart-io.SecureSocket.skipWhile.test.

Error and done events are provided by the returned stream unmodified.

Starting with the first data event where dart-io.SecureSocket.skipWhile.test returns false for the event data, the returned stream will have the same events as this stream.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

distinct.name: distinct
distinct.comment:
Skips data events if they are equal to the previous data event.

The returned stream provides the same events as this stream, except that it never provides two consequtive data events that are equal.

Equality is determined by the provided dart-io.SecureSocket.distinct.equals method. If that is omitted, the '==' operator on the last provided data element is used.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

firstWhere.name: firstWhere
firstWhere.comment:
Finds the first element of this stream matching dart-io.SecureSocket.firstWhere.test.

Returns a future that is filled with the first element of this stream that dart-io.SecureSocket.firstWhere.test returns true for.

If no such element is found before this stream is done, and a dart-io.SecureSocket.firstWhere.defaultValue function is provided, the result of calling dart-io.SecureSocket.firstWhere.defaultValue becomes the value of the future.

Stops listening to the stream after the first matching element has been received.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after the first element that matches the predicate. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this method.

If an error occurs, or if this stream ends without finding a match and with no dart-io.SecureSocket.firstWhere.defaultValue function provided, the future will receive an error.

lastWhere.name: lastWhere
lastWhere.comment:
Finds the last element in this stream matching dart-io.SecureSocket.lastWhere.test.

As dart-io.SecureSocket.firstWhere, except that the last matching element is found. That means that the result cannot be provided before this stream is done.

singleWhere.name: singleWhere
singleWhere.comment:
Finds the single element in this stream matching dart-io.SecureSocket.singleWhere.test.

Like lastMatch, except that it is an error if more than one matching element occurs in the stream.

elementAt.name: elementAt
elementAt.comment:
Returns the value of the dart-io.SecureSocket.elementAt.indexth data event of this stream.

Stops listening to the stream after the dart-io.SecureSocket.elementAt.indexth data event has been received.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after these elements. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this method.

If an error event occurs before the value is found, the future completes with this error.

If a done event occurs before the value is found, the future completes with a dart-core.RangeError.

timeout.name: timeout
timeout.comment:
Creates a new stream with the same events as this stream.

Whenever more than dart-io.SecureSocket.timeout.timeLimit passes between two events from this stream, the dart-io.SecureSocket.timeout.onTimeout function is called.

The countdown doesn't start until the returned stream is listened to. The countdown is reset every time an event is forwarded from this stream, or when the stream is paused and resumed.

The dart-io.SecureSocket.timeout.onTimeout function is called with one argument: an dart-async.EventSink that allows putting events into the returned stream. This EventSink is only valid during the call to onTimeout.

If onTimeout is omitted, a timeout will just put a dart-async.TimeoutException into the error channel of the returned stream.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

destroy.name: destroy
destroy.comment:
Destroy the socket in both directions. Calling dart-io.SecureSocket.destroy will make the send a close event on the stream and will no longer react on data being piped to it.

Call close(inherited from dart-io.IOSink) to only close the dart-io.Socket for sending data.

setOption.name: setOption
setOption.comment:
Use dart-io.SecureSocket.setOption to customize the dart-io.RawSocket. See dart-io.SocketOption for available options.

Returns true if the option was set successfully, false otherwise.
